TITLE: Principal land utilization zones
CREATOR: South Australia. Dept. of Lands
FURTHER_INFO:
This map shows the result of George Woodroffe Goyder's survey which was the delineation of land suitable for growing crops and land that could only support grazing. The scale of shades also allows the division of sheep grazing and cattle grazing to be outlinedIt also shows the line of demarcation which came to be known as Goyder's Line.

George Woodroffe Goyder was born in Liverpool, England in 1826. He emigrated to Sydney in 1848 and subsequently moved to Adelaide and joined the South Australian Public Service in 1851. Goyder joined the Department of Lands in 1853 and was appointed Surveyor-General in 1861. As Surveyor-General he undertook several surveys in northern South Australia (1857-1866) and was responsible for determining the line of demarcation between the land suitable for growing crops and the land that was only suitable for pastoral land. This line became known as Goyder's Line. The line lead to the reassessment of leases, but was unpopular.

Goyder's Line has proved to be very accurate, however during years of unusually good rainfall the government, under pressure from farmers wanting to secure land, decided to sell land north of Goyder's Line for growing crops. Goyder was later proved to be correct when many farms north of the line failed due to lack of reliable rainfall.

'Goyder's ghost seems to hover about, if we are to judge by the result of the last two seasons... I have seen five seasons north of [Goyder's Line] and every year, about August, the wheat was in a dying condition... I paid dearly for my folly...'
(The Register, 22 December 1881, page 6e.)

Goyder's line became a common feature on maps of South Australia.
ADDITIONAL_CREATOR: Hambidge, C. M. (Clive Melville), 1888-1950 Sherrah, M. F

TITLE: Register of the rainfall ...
CREATOR: Kingston, George Strickland, 1807-1880
FURTHER_INFO:
George Strickland Kingston was appointed as deputy surveyor general under Colonel William Light, and arrived in South Australia onboard the Cygnet in 1836. After resigning this post in late 1838 he continued to work in the colony as a surveyor, civil engineer, architect and surveyor, and later inspector of public works and, buildings.

Kingston kept records of rainfall at his home on the corner of Grote Street and West Terrace in Adelaide, beginning from January 1839 until mid-December 1879 covering a period of almost 40 years. These records were tabled in parliament and were subsequently published as a parliamentary paper.

He left South Australia in 1880 to travel to India for his health, but died at sea.
ADDITIONAL_CREATOR: South Australia. Parliament. House of Assembly

TITLE: Average rainfall map
FURTHER_INFO:
This map is a visual representation of the rainfall records kept in South Australia up to 1911, and shows Goyder's line of rainfall. The map is coloured to show areas that have similar rainfall with a scale of shades. The boundary of each area is shown by an isohyet, that is, a line connecting places having equal rainfall. There are two inset maps for the Northern Territory and an enlargement for the metropolitan area and adjacent ranges, showing water supply catchments.

The Commonwealtth Bureau of Meteorology was established in 1908 following the federation of the separate colonies to form the Commonwealth of Australia. Records which had been collected by the separate colonies over many years were transferred to the new Commonwealth Bureau, but state bureaus were still essential to the gathering of local data and weather forecasting.

TITLE: More sketches by Babbage
CREATOR: Babbage, Benjamin Herschel, 1815-1878
COVERAGE_REGION: Flinders Ranges and Far North - Outback
FURTHER_INFO:
This sketch book shows views of the country that Benjamin Babbage passed through during his surveying expedition.

Babbage was appointed to undertake a geological and mineralogical survey of South Australia in 1858. The expedition was intended to open up new country and explore the country between Lake Torrens and Lake Gairdner. In addition to seeking mineral resources and grazing lands he was to search for a passage through the apparent barrier of salt lakes that blocked progress to the north. He was equipped for 18 months but was recalled by the government for being too slow. Babbage was replaced by Peter Egerton Warburton just as he found a way through the lakes to the north.

His sketchbook records the areas he explored: mound springs, creeks and the adjacent country. He also drew a chart of the night sky. On the back of some of the pages he recorded some other details, such as his discovery of the body of William Coulthard at Pernatty Creek. Babbage had been in the vicinity some months previous to his grisly find.

TITLE: Murray Bridge looking west from across the river
FURTHER_INFO: The growing town of Murray Bridge sits on the western bank of the river, taking its name from the bridge. Built as a road bridge in 1879 after first being proposed in 1864, by 1886 the bridge was also carrying the railway line to the Victorian border.

TITLE: Opening of the new bridge at Murray Bridge
FURTHER_INFO: Built in 1879 and by 1886 carrying road and rail traffic the bridge at Murray Bridge was carrying an enormous amount of traffic, by 1921 up to 15 goods trains a day used the bridge in addition to road traffic. Road traffic was being delayed for several hours at a time to allow the trains to cross in safety, and accordingly a second bridge solely for the railway was proposed and finally opened in November 1925.

TITLE: Two bridges at Murray Bridge
FURTHER_INFO: The second bridge at Murray Bridge was opened in 1925 and was specifically built to carry rail traffic. The original bridge, built in 1879, was carrying the railway line by 1886, and by early in the 20th century was carrying up to 15 freight trains a day, with road traffic held up for hours. With the building of the second bridge, the first could now revert to carrying road traffic only.

TITLE: Railway bridge pylons
FURTHER_INFO: The second bridge at Murray Bridge was opened in 1925 and was specifically built to carry rail traffic. The original bridge, built in 1879, was carrying the railway line by 1886, and by early in the 20th century was carrying up to 15 freight trains a day, with road traffic held up for hours. With the building of the second bridge, the first could now revert to carrying road traffic only.

TITLE: Bridge building, Murray Bridge
FURTHER_INFO: The first bridge at Murray Bridge was opened in 1879 after being called for as early as 1864. By 1886 it was also carrying the railway line to the Victorian border. By the early 20th century as many as 15 freight trains a day were using the bridge with road traffic sometimes delayed for several hours. A second dedicated rail bridge was called for an opened in November 1925.

TITLE: Punt at Waikerie
CREATOR: Angus, W. J., photographer
FURTHER_INFO:
Ferries or punts provided the first crossings on the River Murray for many years, and still operate in many places today. At Waikerie ia ferry is recorded as operating in 1910 and like many others, was hand operated, later becoming motorised. The ferry shortened the road between Morgan and Renmark, and the first crossing was made 28 September 1910.

During the 1956 River Murray flood the ferry was closed for six months.

TITLE: Car crossing river on punt
FURTHER_INFO: Ferries or punts provided the first crossings on the River Murray for many years, and still operate in many places today. At Waikerie ia ferry is recorded as operating in 1910 and like many others, was hand operated, later becoming motorised. The ferry shortened the road between Morgan and Renmark, and the first crossing was made 28 September 1910.

TITLE: Paringa Punt
CREATOR: Reiners Studio, photographer
FURTHER_INFO:
Paringa ferry like many others was initially hand operated, but subsequently motorised. It operated until 1926 after which access across the River Murray was by the newly constructed Paringa railway and road bridge.

Ferries were subject to sinking, either from inattention or from overcrowding. Nowadays the ferries on the river are operated by the Department of Road Transport and strict traffic regulations are applied. These ferries are designed to carry large vehicles and are very unlike their early predecessors.

TITLE: Plants collected by Babbage
CREATOR: Mueller, Ferdinand, Baron von, 1825-1896
COVERAGE_REGION: Flinders Ranges and Far North - Outback
FURTHER_INFO:
Baron Ferdinand Von Mueller the author of this report was the Director of the Royal Melbourne Botanical Gardens. Mueller was the leading Australian botanist and botanical specimens were frequently submitted to him for examination and identification. His own collecting trips provided valuable additions to the record of Australia flora and in addition to being a prolific writer of papers, he maintained an enormous correspondence worldwide.

The specimens described by Mueller were collected by Benjamin Herschel Babbage during his expedition to the far north of South Australia in 1858. Babbage had been sent north to explore and survey by the South Australian government, to look for pastoral lands, mineral deposits and to conduct a careful survey of the land. However his progress was considered too slow and he was replaced by Peter Egerton Warburton. Babbage discovered and described in detail the first (Emerald Spring) of the numerous mound springs which bubble up from the Great Artesian Basin and provide reliable water in an otherwise waterless land.

TITLE: Goolwa barrage
FURTHER_INFO:
The construction of barrages near the mouth of the Murray had been suggested as early as 1890 because of issues to do with the salinity of the water in the lakes and upstream, and the water levels. Discussion continued into the early years of the 20th century and by 1913 the government was convinced of the need. World War I intervened and it was not until 1922 that the issue was again before the government. Argument and counter argument were put forward and finally in by the 1930s it was decided to proceed, taking advantage of the high unemployment at the time to obtain cheap labour. Construction began in 1935 and was completed in 1940.

There are actually five barrages: Tauwitchere, Ewe Island, Mundoo, Boundary Creek and Goolwa.

TITLE: P.S. Industry
FURTHER_INFO: Lock 3 is at Overland Corner.  PS Industry is a composite paddle steamer built by GB Wilson, Goolwa, in 1911 and was designed by AJ Inches. The boat was used for lock repairs, snagging and dredging by the South Australian Government and later by the River Murray Commission. It was extensively refitted in 1933. It now stands at Renmark where it is open for inspection daily and operates once a month.

TITLE: Renmark Lock 5
FURTHER_INFO: The lock and weir at Renmark was completed in 1927, the third to be built in South Australia.

TITLE: Weir and lock at Renmark
FURTHER_INFO: The lock at Renmark is No. 5 Lock, but was the third to be built in South Australia. Part of the early 20th century scheme to harness and control River Murray flows for irrigation and the paddle steamer trade the first lock built was the Wiliam R. Randell Lock at Blanchetown, opened in 1922. In South Australia the last lock built was at Murtho in 1930. There are a further four locks on the river east of the border.

TITLE: Tarella at Blanchetown Lock
FURTHER_INFO:
Blanchetown lock is No. 1 Lock, the William R. Randell Lock named after the pioneering paddle steamer operator William Randell who was the first to operate his paddle steamer Mary Ann on the river in 1853. Lock no. 1 was completed in 1922.

Tarella was built in 1897, with a steel frame and redgum bottom. She had accomodation for 20 passengers, but was also a reliable and stalwart carrier, as in 1907 with two barges in tow she was reported as carrying 1711 bales of wool and on another occasion 7500 bags of wheat.

TITLE: Waikeri
FURTHER_INFO: The South Australian government established the provisions for the founding of communal settlements, known as village settlements, in a part of the Crown Lands Amendment Act in 1893. Settlers arrived at Waikerie at the beginning of March in 1894.

TITLE: Waikeri
FURTHER_INFO: The South Australian government established the provisions for the founding of communal settlements, known as village settlements, in a part of the Crown Lands Amendment Act in 1893. Settlers arrived at Waikerie at the beginning of March in 1894.

TITLE: Village settlements : Waikeri
FURTHER_INFO: The South Australian government established the provisions for the founding of communal settlements, known as village settlements, in a part of the Crown Lands Amendment Act in 1893. Settlers arrived at Waikerie at the beginning of March in 1894. In July 1894 by 18 disgruntled settlers from the Waikerie village settlement established a new settlement, Ramco.

TITLE: Paringa Bridge and Punt
CREATOR: Reiners' Studio
FURTHER_INFO:
The Paringa punt is motorised in this image and is in its final days of operation as the Paringa road and rail bridge nears completion. The bridge was officially opened 31 January 1927 and the punt was discontinued and eventually re-located to Lyrup.

The tall centre section of the bridge allows for the passage underneath of paddleboat steamers with their tall funnels.

TITLE: Tailem Bend punt
FURTHER_INFO: The ferry at Tailem Bend was one of the last built across the River Murray by the South Australian government. It was a vital link between Jervois and Tailem Bend. Built in 1924 with a timber jetty, it was replaced in the 1960s by a new punt and crossing.

TITLE: Punt at Berri
CREATOR: Gray, F. Malcolm; photographer
FURTHER_INFO:
A ferry service was provided across the river from 1910 and until 1961 a range of fees were charged, for instance in 1938 it cost an adult one penny each way (roughly one cent), and half a farthing for each head of sheep.

A bridge replaced the ferry in 1997.

TITLE: Goolwa tramway
CREATOR: Government Photolithographer, photographer
FURTHER_INFO:
The Goolwa-Port Elliot railway was the first railway in South Australia, although it was horse-drawn not steam. It was only seven miles long. The railway was officially finished on 18 May 1854, and in 1864 was extended to Victor Harbor, after it was decided that the Port Elliot anchorage was dangerous. 

The railway had been first proposed in 1849. The successful navigation of the river by William Randell and Francis Cadell in 1853 gave urgency to the project, and despite labour and materials shortages, the line went ahead and was finished in May 1854. Goods from properties along the river could now be off-loaded at Goolwa, transported by rail to Port Elliot, later to Victor Harbor, and shipped to the world.

The line was finally converted to steam in 1885.

TITLE: First Railway Coach, Goolwa
FURTHER_INFO:
The Goolwa-Port Elliot railway was the first railway in South Australia, although it was horse-drawn not steam. It was only seven miles long. The railway was officially finished on 18 May 1854, and in 1864 was extended to Victor Harbor, after it was decided that the Port Elliot anchorage was dangerous. 

The railway had been first proposed in 1849. The successful navigation of the river by William Randell and Francis Cadell in 1853 gave urgency to the project, and despite labour and materials shortages, the line went ahead and was finished in May 1854. Goods from properties along the river could now be off-loaded at Goolwa, transported by rail to Port Elliot, later to Victor Harbor, and shipped to the world. The line was finally converted to steam in 1885.

The railway carriage is now housed behind glass, adjacent to the Goolwa Post Office.

TITLE: Goolwa and Port Elliot horse tram
CREATOR: Australian Photographic Co., photographer
FURTHER_INFO:
The Goolwa-Port Elliot railway was the first railway in South Australia, although it was horse-drawn not steam. It was only seven miles long. The railway was officially finished on 18 May 1854, and in 1864 was extended to Victor Harbor, after it was decided that the Port Elliot anchorage was dangerous. 

The railway had been first proposed in 1849. The successful navigation of the river by William Randell and Francis Cadell in 1853 gave urgency to the project, and despite labour and materials shortages, the line went ahead and was finished in May 1854. Goods from properties along the river could now be off-loaded at Goolwa, transported by rail to Port Elliot, later to Victor Harbor, and shipped to the world.

The line was finally converted to steam in 1885.

The station is possibly Goolwa.

TITLE: Newly opened country lands ...Ramsay
CREATOR: South Australia. Surveyor-General's Office
FURTHER_INFO:
This map of country areas in South Australia from various regions, shows land for sale by name of Hundred. The detail shows topography, section numbers, description of vegetation, soil and arability of the land. The Hundreds shown are Ramsay, Gregory, Angus, English, Coomooroo, Boolcunda and Kuitpo. These areas were surveyed by the Surveyor-General at that time, George W. Goyder. He believed land should be surveyed before selection was made by would-be purchasers.

George Woodroffe Goyder was born in Liverpool, England in 1826. He emigrated to Sydney in 1848 and subsequently moved to Adelaide and joined the South Australian public service in 1851. Goyder joined the Department of Lands in 1853 and was appointed Surveyor-General in 1861. As Surveyor-General he undertook several surveys in northern South Australia (1857-1866) and was responsible for determining the line of demarcation between agricultural and pastoral land, which became known as Goyder's Line.

The line was based upon a survey of rainfall taken by Goyder, which allowed him to determine which areas received adequate rainfall to support agriculture and which was only suitable for grazing. Demand for more agricultural land and several seasons of above average rainfall encouraged the Government and farmers to ignore Goyder's survey result, and to extend farming to the north of Goyder's Line, resulting in the ruin of many farmers.

TITLE: Interview with Iolanda Devito
CREATOR: Devito, Iolanda
FURTHER_INFO: Iolanda Devito was born in southern Italy and migrated to Australia in 1936. She and her husband established themselves in Waikerie, eventually buying their own property. In the selection presented here, Iolanda and her daugheter talk about how when many Italians in Australia were interned during the Second World War Iolanda's husband was not because it was deemed that it would be more beneficial for him to remain on the land to supply fruit and vegetables.

TITLE: Government stables, Goolwa
CREATOR: Viney, E. I., photographer
FURTHER_INFO:
This substantial masonry building with brick quoins was built in 1862 replacing an earlier structure. It accomodated the horse teams for the railways and coincides with the period when riverboat and railway traffic on the line was increasing. From 1885 traction on the railway became steam and the stables became vacant.

The building is now occupied by the Goolwa sub-branch of the Returned Services League (RSL).

TITLE: Remarks on the Riverina trade and proposed Murray railway
CREATOR: Laughton, Edward
FURTHER_INFO: The author argues the case for a railway line to the Northwest Bend (Morgan) of the Murray, rather than a line across the river at Murray Bridge. The railway to Morgan at the bend opened in 1878, and despite Laughton's argument against the railway line, crossed the bridge at Murray Bridge as well in 1886, continuing to the Victorian border.

TITLE: Morgan train 1896
FURTHER_INFO:
The railway to Morgan at the north west bend on the River Murray opened in 1878 and was an extension of the line to Kapunda. It carried freight from the paddle steamers such as wool and grain, later dried fruits from the irrigation colonies down to Port Adelaide and brought back to the river goods and equipment for the further development of the interior. The wharf was extensive and steam cranes were installed to expedite the shifting of cargo from the paddle steamers. Traffic on the railway grew quickly with up to six trains a day travelling between Port Adelaide and Morgan. The railway made Morgan the busiest port on the river.

Usage of the railway declined after World War II with the growing impact of road services and improved road conditions. The last passenger train to Morgan was in March 1965 and the line was closed in 1969 and the track removed soon after.

TITLE: Train leaving Morgan
FURTHER_INFO:
The railway to Morgan at the north west bend on the River Murray opened in 1878 and was an extension of the line to Kapunda. It carried freight from the paddle steamers such as wool and grain, later dried fruits from the irrigation colonies down to Port Adelaide and brought back to the river goods and equipment for the further development of the interior. The wharf was extensive and steam cranes were installed to expedite the shifting of cargo from the paddle steamers. Traffic on the railway grew quickly with up to six trains a day travelling between Port Adelaide and Morgan. The railway made Morgan the busiest port on the river.

A H Landseer

Usage of the railway declined after World War II with the growing impact of road services and improved road conditions. The last passenger train to Morgan was in March 1965 and the line was closed in 1969 and the track removed soon after.

TITLE: Wheat stack at the Loxton landing
FURTHER_INFO: The wheat harvest always coincided with low water on the river, and thousands of bags of wheat would be stacked up on the wharf awaiting transport to market. Loxton successfully argued for railway to carry the harvest to Port Adelaide for shipment overseas. In 1914 the new railway was opened with wheat the main shipment out and the fertilizer superphosphate on the return. The railway station is now part of an historical pioneer village.

TITLE: Wheat stack in Loxton railway yard
FURTHER_INFO:
The wheat harvest always coincided with low water on the river, and thousands of bags of wheat would be stacked up on the wharf awaiting transport to market. Loxton successfully argued for railway to carry the harvest to Port Adelaide for shipment overseas. In 1914 the new railway was opened with wheat the main shipment out and the fertilizer superphosphate on the return. The railway station is now part of an historical pioneer village.

Wheat was bagged in the farm paddock and transported to the town: each bag contained about 4 bushels (or 110 kgs). After 1909 the bags were a little smaller holding 72 kgs or 3 bushels. At the grain agents' yards the bags were tallied and then loaded onto the stacks awaiting shipment by rail or sea. The stacks were usually 23 bags high.

TITLE: Paringa Renmark Railway
FURTHER_INFO:
Morgan at the North west bend of the river had a railway in 1879, and the road bridge at Murray Bridge was also carrying a railway line by 1886. The Riverland was not served by railways until the 20th century with Loxton lobbying for a railway in 1910. The wheat harvest always coincided with low water on the river, and thousands of bags of wheat would be stacked up on the wharf awaiting transport to market. The government approved a spur line from Alawoona in 1912. 

Other river towns also began to agitate for railway lines: the Paringa station was opened on 13 October 1913. The Waikerie line was completed in December 1914. It was not until September 1925 that a bridge was approved to cross the river at Renmark. This would include road and rail, and a lifting span for paddle-steamers. The line to Renmark was further extended to Berri, Glossop and Barmera, where the first train arrived on 1 August 1928.

The railways through the Mallee to the river served the region well, but better roads and bigger road transport in turn superseded them.

TITLE: Renmark Paringa bridge opening
FURTHER_INFO:
Morgan at the North West bend of the river had a railway in 1879, and the road bridge at Murray Bridge was also carrying a railway line by 1886. The Riverland was not served by railways until the 20th century with Loxton lobbying for a railway in 1910. The wheat harvest always coincided with low water on the river making transport downstream a problem, and thousands of bags of wheat would be stacked up on the wharf awaiting transport to market. The government approved a spur line from Alawoona in 1912. 

Other river towns also began to agitate for railway lines: the Paringa station was opened on 13 October 1913. The Waikerie line was completed in December 1914. It was not until September 1925 that a bridge was approved to cross the river at Renmark from Paringa. This would include road and rail, and a lifting span for paddle-steamers. The line to Renmark was further extended to Berri, Glossop and Barmera, where the first train arrived on 1 August 1928.

The railways through the Mallee to the river served the region well, but better roads and bigger road transport in turn superseded them.

TITLE: First train, Renmark Railway
FURTHER_INFO:
It took until September 1925 for a bridge to be approved to cross the river at Renmark. This would include road and rail, and a lifting span for paddle-steamers and would extend the Paringa line across the river. Paringa station was opened on 13 October 1913 but World War I intervened and there was a considerable delay in extending the line to Renmark.

Morgan at the North west bend of the river had a railway in 1879, and the road bridge at Murray Bridge was also carrying a railway line by 1886. The Riverland was not served by railways until the 20th century with Loxton lobbying for a railway in 1910. The wheat harvest always coincided with low water on the river, and thousands of bags of wheat would be stacked up on the wharf awaiting transport to market. The government approved a spur line from Alawoona in 1912. The Waikerie line was completed in December 1914.  The line to Renmark was further extended to Berri, Glossop and Barmera, where the first train arrived on 1 August 1928.

The railways through the Mallee to the river served the region well, but better roads and bigger road transport in turn superseded them

TITLE: The William R. Randell Lock, Blanchetown, River Murray ...
FURTHER_INFO:
The ceremony for the laying of the stone to begin work on the first lock on the River Murray, the William R Randell Lock at Blanchetown, includes speeches from the Premiers of South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales, Governor of South Australia, Prime Minister and various other dignitaries. The speeches summarise the years of negotiation to reach this point, the interstate cooperation and the benefits the locks will bring. The lock was completed in 1922.

ADDITIONAL_CREATOR: South Australia. Intelligence and Tourist Bureau

TITLE: Low River, Renmark
FURTHER_INFO: Low water on the River Murray at the end of summer or during droughts meant the paddle steamers could not move on the river: many were stranded upstream sometimes for several years during droughts. With the advent of the irrigation colonies from the late 1880s there was a further demand for a constant and reliable water supply. After many years of arguing regarding the river the states finally signed an agreement in 1915 which would allow the erection of locks and weirs along the river to regulate the flow of water. Work on the first lock at Blanchetown began in 1915 but was not completed until 1922 due to World War I. The remaining locks were completed by 1935, by which time the river boat trade was already in decline. Water levels still need to be maintained for irrigation, the demand for which continued to increase.

TITLE: Construction of No.1 Lock, Blanchetown
FURTHER_INFO: The lock was named the William R. Randell Lock after William Randell the first man to operate a paddlesteamer on the River Murray in 1853. Randell went on to build up a successful freight business on the river with a sizeable fleet of paddlesteamers and also operated a dry dock at Mannum.

TITLE: Paddle steamer Gem, Waikerie
FURTHER_INFO: Six locks were to be constructed on the South Australian section of the River Murray: at Blanchetown, Waikerie, Renmark, Murtho (Paringa), Kingston (Overland Corner) and Berri (Bookpurnong). Of these Blanchetown (Lock no. 1) was completed in 1922. The lock at Waikerie (Lock no. 2) was not completed until 1928 and was the fourth to be built.

TITLE: Lock Chamber, Renmark
FURTHER_INFO: Renmark was Lock no. 5 and it was completed in 1927, the third of the six locks on the South Australian stretch of the River Murray to be completed.

TITLE: Building materials for Lock 6
FURTHER_INFO: Lock 6 was at Murtho (Paringa) and was the last lock in South Australia before the river passed the border into new South Wales/Victoria. Lock 6 was completed in 1930.

TITLE: Barrage construction at Goolwa
FURTHER_INFO:
The construction of barrages near the mouth of the Murray had been suggested as early as 1890 because of issues to do with the salinity of the water in the lakes and upstream, and the water levels. Discussion continued into the early years of the 20th century and by 1913 the government was convinced of the need. World War I intervened and it was not until 1922 that the issue was again before the government. Argument and counter argument were put forward and finally in by the 1930s it was decided to proceed, taking advantage of the high unemployment at the time to obtain cheap labour. Construction began in 1935 and was completed in 1940.

There are actually five barrages: Tauwitchere, Ewe Island, Mundoo, Boundary Creek and Goolwa.

TITLE: P.S. Marion, Overland Corner
FURTHER_INFO:
Overland Corner is Lock 3 on the River Murray and was completed in 1925.

PS Marion was built in 1897 and is now a fully restored operational paddle steamer operating out of Mannum. After her working life was over, she was moved to Mannun in 1963 where she was for many years a static display. A dedicated team of volunteers began full restoration in the 1990s.

TITLE: Assistance from Aboriginal peoples
CREATOR: Sturt, Charles, 1795-1869
FURTHER_INFO:
Sturt records the assistance given to him by the Aboriginal people throughout his voyage down the river and again upstream. He writes how each community passed him along to the next down river and of how they described changes that he would meet, such as the big bend where the river finally turned south. Without their assistance on the return voyage, the explorers would have had great difficulty in surmounting the rapids they had sailed down with relative ease. Sturt also records that the Aboriginals were sadly afflicted by some terrible disease, which he thought was smallpox.

Read pdf extracts of the book (312 kb)

TITLE: Sturt charts the river
CREATOR: Sturt, Charles, 1795-1869
FURTHER_INFO:
Sturt describes how he charted the river as the boat travelled downstream, recording its twists and turns and the nature of the country adjacent to the river. This chart was of great assistance on their return trip back upstream as it provided a guide to the distances they had travelled and the sites of their previous camps.

The extracts are pp. 146/47 and 188/89 from volume 2 of Two expeditons into the interior of southern Australia, during the years 1828, 1829, 1830, and 1831 ...

TITLE: Junction of the Darling and Murray
CREATOR: Sturt, Charles, 1795-1869
FURTHER_INFO: Sturt gives his reasoning for his assumption that the large river which entered the Murray at this point was the River Darling, which he had discovered further upstream in February 1829.

TITLE: Concentration camp
CREATOR: Dubotzky, Paul, photographer
FURTHER_INFO: Over 300 'enemy aliens' were interned at the Torrens Island Concentration Camp, in the harbour of Port Adelaide, South Australia, during the First World War. Internees were mainly of German or Austro-Hungarian background.

TITLE: Who discovered Lake Alexandrina
CREATOR: Gill, Thomas
COVERAGE_REGION: Mt Lofty Ranges and Eastern Plain
FURTHER_INFO: Charles Sturt was not the first European to discover Lake Alexandrina, although he believed so at the time. News eventually reached Sydney that a large lake adjacent to the coast of Encounter Bay had been seen by sealers operating on the south coast. A report of this was sent to Sydney, but its arrival was delayed. The sealers did not realise that a large river drained into the lake.
ADDITIONAL_CREATOR: Royal Geographical Society of Australasia. South Australian Branch Pitt, G. H. Zalums, E.

TITLE: Der Kamerad : Wochenschrift der Kriegsgefangenen
FURTHER_INFO:
Over 350 'enemy aliens' were interned at the Torrens Island Concentration Camp which opened on 9 October 1914. Internment in Australia was regulated by the War Precautions Act 1914. Internees were mainly of German or Austro-Hungarian background, including some who were naturalised British citizens. Some internees were crew members of enemy nationality who were taken from ships in Australian ports. In South Australia, a relatively high percentage of migrants were of German background, and so the 'enemy alien' concept had a significant effect. Not all were held as internees in camps; some were required to report to local police on a regular basis.

Torrens Island Internment Camp '... had by far the worst reputation of all internment camps in the Commonwealth' (Fischer, p. 194) with primitive living conditions and harsh ill-treatment of prisoners. The third issue of Der Kamerad reported that captured escapees had been flogged. After the findings of a court of enquiry into this treatment of internees was submitted, the Defence Department closed the camp on 16 August 1915. The federal government had also decided to close regional camps that had been set up in the early years of the war. Many prisoners, including South Australian internees, were transferred to Holdsworthy camp near Liverpool in New South Wales.

TITLE: Buchanan: overlander
CREATOR: Buchanan, Alexander
FURTHER_INFO:
Alexander Buchanan was part of the second wave of overlanders that followed in the tracks of Hawdon and Bonney, Eyre and Sturt. It was this second wave that began to experience serious difficulties with the Aboriginal communities along the river, particularly those adjacent to the Rufus River as they responded to what appeared to be wholesale invasion of their lands. Buchanan was the only overlander who admitted that he deliberately attacked the Aborigines in retaliation for their acts against his party.

With a number of companions he drove a large flock of sheep which included another 5000 for Frederick Dutton of Anlaby. The men with their huge flock travelled down the Murrumbidgee River and after crossing the Lachlan River travelled across country to pick up the River Murray about 20 miles east of the junction with the Darling. At the North West Bend (Morgan) they left the river travelling across country again to Anlaby where Dutton's sheep were left, before taking the remainder on down to Adelaide.

Buchanan would later become the manager of Anlaby station for Dutton.

TITLE: Fatal encounter with Aboriginal people on the Murray
FURTHER_INFO: In August 1841, the Aboriginal community at the Rufus River attacked William Robinson's party of 25 men overlanding some 6000 sheep and other stock. About 15 Aboriginal people were killed. The next day a relief party sent out from Adelaide joined them and following an attack while fording the river, a further 30 Aboriginal people were killed, while a number were wounded and four were taken prisoner. This incident has become known as the Rufus River massacre, and a government enquiry was held.

TITLE: Loxton irrigation scheme approved
FURTHER_INFO: The commitment to open up land at Loxton for Soldier Settlers after World War Two completely changed the character and economy of the area. The local newspaper, The Murray Pioneer, reports on the state government's announcement of approval for the Loxton Irrigation Scheme as part of the federal government's Soldier Settlement Program, following heavy lobbying by the Returned Services League and the Father's Association.

TITLE: Early days of settlement
FURTHER_INFO: The South Australian government established the provisions for the founding of communal settlements, known as village settlements, in a part of the Crown Lands Amendment Act in 1893. Thirteen village settlements were eventually founded in South Australia. Of these, eleven were on the River Murray.

TITLE: Memorandum of association and rules of the Murtho Co-Operative Village Association
CREATOR: Murtho Co-Operative Village Association
FURTHER_INFO:
The South Australian government established the provisions for the founding of communal settlements, known as village settlements, in a part of the Crown Lands Amendment Act in 1893. The Murtho village settlement began on 19 July 1894. Murtho was the only village settlement to require some capital from settlers before being allowed to join - £40 for unmarried settlers, £60 for married and £10 per child.

This pamphlet outlines the rules of the Murtho village settlement. It also details the powers of the village association board, including the authority to expel members.

TITLE: Report of the Select Committee on village settlements...
CREATOR: South Australia. Parliament
FURTHER_INFO:
The South Australian government established the provisions for the founding of communal settlements, known as village settlements, in a part of the Crown Lands Amendment Act in 1893. Amendments to the way in which the village settlements were administered were proposed in late 1895 and a Parliamentary Committee of Enquiry was established to investigate the condition of the settlements. The Committee travelled to all of the village settlements and took evidence from the settlers.

In this selection from the minutes of evidence of the report of the select committee on village settlements, a settler from New Residence reports that he does not believe the settlement will be able to clear its debts.

TITLE: Report of the Select Committee on village settlements...
CREATOR: South Australia. Parliament
FURTHER_INFO: The South Australian government established the provisions for the founding of communal settlements, known as village settlements, in a part of the Crown Lands Amendment Act in 1893. Amendments to the way in which the village settlements were administered were proposed in late 1895 and a Parliamentary Committee of Enquiry was established to investigate the condition of the settlements. The Committee travelled to all of the village settlements and took evidence from the settlers. In this selection from the minutes of evidence of the report of the select committee on village settlements, a settler reports on the number of settlers, rations and cost of living at Moorook. It also shows the attitude towards women of some of the male settlers.

TITLE: Lacepede Bay depicted
CREATOR: Lesueur, Charles Alexandre, 1778-1846
FURTHER_INFO:
These seven coastal profiles of the Victorian and South Australian coast were drawn for Nicolas Baudin's expedition of 1800-1803. Line 3 is of Lacepede Bay near Cape Bernouilli (now Cape Jaffa) in the south-east and Line 4 is of part of Fleurieu Peninsula. In line 5 (K) shows Ile Turenne which is actually Waterhouse Point on Thistle Island in Spencer Gulf; (L) Ile Lagrange is Boston Island. Lines 6 and 7 show portions of the west coast of the state, with (Q) Ile Cuvier being Olive's Island. In the era before photography the profiles of newly discovered coasts formed an important part of the descriptions of new found lands, enabling later travellers along these coasts to identify exactly where they were. For us today they give views of the coast before settlement and colonisation changed the appearance of the land.

Born in Le Havre in January 1778, Charles-Alexandre Lesueur was the son of a naval officer. He loved drawing, especially natural history, and wanted to travel to far off lands. He joined the Baudin expedition as a crew member, and like fellow artist Nicolas-Martin Petit was able to take over as an expedition artist when the official artists resigned. Lesueur became the natural history artist, and his images of Australia's exotic marine life are particularly striking. He was a friend of the expedition's chief scientist Francois P ©ron, and when P ©ron became ill after the expedition had returned to France, Lesueur nursed him until his death in 1810. In 1815 Lesueur went to the United States and travelled extensively there and in the West Indies before deciding to settle in Philadelphia. Lesueur stayed in the United States for 25 years, where he discovered a number of zoological species including tortoises and fishes. He taught painting, and was elected a member of the American Philosophical Society, and of the Academy of Natural Sciences. Lesueur returned to France in 1837, and in 1845 went back to Le Havre to oversee the building of the Natural History Museum. He became this museum's first Director. Lesueur died in 1846, having been awarded the Legion of Honour in the previous year.

TITLE: New Era village settlement
FURTHER_INFO:
New Era was established on 25 April 1894 and was the second of the village settlements to dissolve, doing so in March 1896.

This brief newspaper article shows the worsening situation at New Era.

TITLE: Report of the Select Committee on village settlements...
CREATOR: South Australia. Parliament
FURTHER_INFO:
The South Australian government established the provisions for the founding of communal settlements, known as village settlements, in a part of the Crown Lands Amendment Act in 1893. Amendments to the way in which the village settlements were administered were proposed in late 1895 and a Parliamentary Committee of Enquiry was established to investigate the condition of the settlements. The Committee travelled to all of the village settlements and took evidence from the settlers.

In this selection from the report of the select committee on village settlements summarises the evidence given by the New Era settlers.

TITLE: Wooden panel for 150th anniversary
CREATOR: Dunstan, Douglas A.
FURTHER_INFO:
Douglas Dunstan was the managing director of the Griffin Press, having learned the printing business in Queensland and then serving as manager of the Advertiser Printing Office, a division of the Adelaide Advertiser. He brought high standards to the printery and in 1954 this became the Griffin Press. As well as producing paperbacks and general publications, the standards of excellence he insisted upon at the press resulted in a number of books for the Limited Editions Club of New York being designed and printed in Adelaide.

Dunstan retired in 1967 but maintained his interest in book design. He also developed an interest in wood carving executing a number of panels for the Beaumont Uniting Church, and donating several others to the State Library. One of these encapsulates the history and development of South Australia and was presented as part of the Jubilee 150 celebrations.

TITLE: Wheat costume
CREATOR: Richardson, Mimi
FURTHER_INFO:
This is the lowest of three tiers of the costume if we judge by the stains along the hemline which could not be removed during conservation. The rich golden colour of the silk and the fine pleating reflects the waving movement of a field of wheat just prior to harvest. The costume also included a head piece of wheat stalks.

Thelma Afford, the costume designer for the heritage pageant, produced many stunning and imaginative designs for agriculture and industry, as well as the historical costumes of the pioneers.

In 1986 she donated to the Mortlock Library, 80 of the original costume designs which she had created for the 1936 South Australian Centenary pageant. Thelma Thomas Afford was a gifted teacher of art and a prolific costume designer, working in Adelaide, Melbourne and Sydney from the 1930s to the 1950s. She was married to the playwright Max Afford.

In 1936 South Australia celebrated 100 years since the foundation of the state as a British colony, producing histories, plays and exhibitions to mark the achievements of the century. The grand finale of the year's celebrations was the 'Pageant of Progress', held in December.

Thelma Afford was a talented designer, exploring uses of various media for her costume work, and was a recognised authority on the history of costume and theatre in Australia. Her designs for the 1936 special events included innovative interpretations of technology as well as agricultural products and flora and fauna. With her background in the history of costume, she also brought authenticity to her designs of the dress of significant early settlers.

TITLE: Ethiopian manuscript book
FURTHER_INFO:
Written on vellum in Ge'ez, the ancient Ethiopian church language, this well-worn manuscript book, with wooden covers, contains psalms and hymns from the Old Testament, the Song of Solomon, and prayers to the Virgin Mary.

Although it looks medieval, the volume is thought to date from the 19th century.

It was stored in a stained camel-skin, two-piece case, with straps. The case still smells of the campfires around which the book's readers once sat.

Donated by the Friends of the State Library.
